title: Root to be named Test captain
text:
England to name Joe Root as Alastair Cook's replacement as Test captain By Andy Charles Last Updated: 13/02/17 10:23am Joe Root will be named as England's Test captain later today, according to Sky sources Joe Root is to be confirmed as Alastair Cook's replacement as England Test captain later on Monday, Sky sources understand. 
The 26-year-old will take charge for the first time against South Africa in July replacing Cook, who resigned earlier this months after four years in charge. 
The Yorkshire all-rounder will become England's 80th Test captain when that series gets underway, with his first game in charge coming at Lord's. Root has scored 4,594 runs since he made his Test debut in December 2012 
He is expected to be presented to the media at Headingley on Wednesday. 
Root had been Cook's vice-captain since 2015 and was seen as one of three leading candidates to replace the opener, along with Stuart Broad and Ben Stokes. 
Cook stepped down on February 6 after thinking about his future as captain in the wake of the 4-0 Test series defeat in India, one he said had left him "drained". Alastair Cook says it is the right time for him to step down as England captain, admitting he feels he can no longer commit 100% to the role 
Root will have time to settle into the role with England concentrating mainly on 50-over cricket until July. 
They head to the West Indies for three one-day internationals in early March and then play two games against Ireland before the ICC Champions Trophy begins on June 1. Also See:
